Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: University of Florida Unites Teachers to Reform Education in Science: Preparing a New Generation of Middle Grades Science Teacher Leaders (U-FUTuRES 2.0)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovation Corps for Learning Program (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to increase the scale and impact of a professional development model to transform middle grades science teaching and learning. Our nation's middle grades science teachers, the portal to science engagement and success in high school and beyond, are overwhelmingly under prepared to meet certification requirements and public expectations for student performance in science. Many middle grades science teachers complete a college degree in a field other than science or science education. This transformative, classroom-focused, field-tested professional learning program has the potential to simultaneously bolster middle grades science teachers? disciplinary content knowledge and teaching skills. This I-Corps L team project addresses the pressing national need for stronger middle grades science teachers.

The U-FUTuRES 2.0 model (University of Florida Unites Teachers to Reform Education in Science v.2) will be expanded from the current model of district, school, and classroom reform to respond to the pressing national need for improved science teaching. Current coursework developed through a collaborative effort between science educators and partnering scientists at the University of Florida, will deepen middle grades science teachers' content knowledge and transform their classroom approach to an inquiry-based, learning-goals-driven, highly engaging and challenging science learning experience for all their students. Incorporated in this innovation will be strategies for establishing a partnership with school and district leaders striving to support both the development and broader impact of their science teacher leaders in their schools and districts. It is expected that the proposed innovation in professional learning and leadership development will result in increasing teachers' knowledge of disciplinary core science concepts, science and engineering practices and cross-cutting concepts, transformed teaching practice, and improved student engagement and learning outcomes. The project goal is to prepare middle grades students for success in rigorous high school science courses, the gateway to STEM educational opportunities and careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I-Corps L: University of Florida Unites Teachers to Reform Education in Science: Preparing a New Generation of Middle Grades Science Teacher Leaders (U-FUTuRES 2.0)

 

Over the past six years, science educators at the University of Florida’s College of Education have built a partnership to provide high-quality, job-embedded professional development for middle school science teachers. The program, in collaboration with scientists, is seeking to increase students’ science achievement across the state of Florida and beyond. Developed with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF), U-FUTuRES, short for University of Florida Unites Teachers to Reform Education in Science, deepened participating teachers’ science content knowledge, enhanced their inquiry-based science teaching skills, and provided training in leadership.

With the support of an additional $50,000.00 NSF grant, the dynamic U-FUTuRES team of Natalie King, Lynda Hayes, and Rose Pringle participated in the 2015 NSF Innovation Corps for Learning (I-Corps L) summer program to scale and sustain their innovative professional development ideas. This practical experience trained the team in the use of the Lean Startup method and a business-modeling tool to focus and organize their efforts. The team also gained experience with methods and strategies for customer development, hypotheses testing, and pivoting.  They strategically conducted 135 interviews across eight different states to refine their thinking about how to offer high-quality professional development, and develop a winning model for teachers and districts. Their resulting business model was selected as the top plan out of 20 competing teams participating in the 2015 I-Corps L summer program.

Rebranded as U-FUTuRES 2.0, the professional development program was transformed into a one-year accelerated, job-embedded STEM certificate program. This pioneering program consisting of five, 8-week online courses, is designed to create an accelerated pathway to expertise in 4th-8th grade science teaching. Two courses focus on deepening teachers’ science content knowledge specifically in disciplinary core ideas and crosscutting concepts as indicated in the Framework for K-12 Science Education and correlated to state standards. Three science education courses focus on reform-based science teaching, science curriculum development and assessment, and best practices for engaging students from underrepresented populations. All five courses were co-developed, tested, and refined by a team of UF scientists and science educators and science and science education graduate students. All team members have had much experiences teaching K-8 science teachers.    

At the start of fall 2015, the U-FUTuRES 2.0 team continued to engage in customer development and made substantive adjustments to the program. This was followed by an aggressive marketing campaign that included the development of an advertising brochure (U-FUTuRES 2.0 Brochure) and other promotional materials for use during negotiations with administrators from schools and districts. Forty-six science teachers began the first course in the certificate program in January 2016 supported by funding from their school districts.  The school district of St. Lucie county funded 26 teachers and district leaders to participate in the STEM certificate program. The school districts of Nassau and Clay counties supported 10 teachers to participate in the STEM certificate program, and an additional 15 teachers to enroll in the Inquiry-Based Science Teaching course (SCE 5316) to learn practices of reform-based science instruction. The first cohort of 36 teachers completed the U-FUTuRES 2.0 STEM certificate program in fall 2016 and 14 teachers have continued in the department toward the completion of the MAE in science education. A second cohort of teachers are now enrolled and will complete the program in fall 2017. To date, U-FUTuRES 2.0 program has impacted over 7000 students in the state of Florida and a national marketing plan is underway to secure the next cohort of teachers.
